page.title: 15Birdwatching on the Eyebrook
page.content: Many ornithologists visit the Eyebrook armed with binoculars,telescopes and cameras observing the many flocks, always hoping to see a rarity.Views from the road are good and uninterr- upted.The walk through the plantation on the eastern side is often less rewarding as far as gulls and water fowl are concerned,but it is very plea sant with lovely views of the lake. Tiny goldcrests call from the tops of the firs,Swans may be seen gliding majestically,or even a solitary heron, still and statuesque standing in the shallows.In summer swifts and swallows swoop low over the lake to catch insects.Yellow wagtails flit along the hedgerowa and amongst the grazing cattle.The autumn migration sees many visitors,teal,wigeon,gadwall,shorelles and greylag geese. Rarities include snowgeese,Bewick swans and cormorant.
